# Discord Chat Analysis for ğŸ’»â”‚developers

## 1. Summary
The discussion primarily focused on elevator physics implementation and animation blending in a game development context. Gert-Jan Akerboom encountered issues with elevator collision detection - when using kinematic collision with convex ON, players couldn't enter the elevator due to invisible collision at the entrance, but with convex OFF, players fell through the bottom. Ashxn provided a solution using setKinematicTarget inside fixedUpdate ticks while ensuring the rigidbody is in world space, which resulted in smooth elevator movement. 

Ashxn also mentioned working on animation blending and layers to apply animations over locomotion animations, noting challenges with jarring transitions between running forward and strafing animations. They're seeking better base locomotion animations where primarily the legs move while the body remains relatively idle.

Other topics briefly discussed included a new dot crosshair interface element (replacing a larger circle), particle portal effects, and a question about obtaining screen dimensions for UI development in a Hyp app.

## 2. FAQ
Q: How do I fix elevator collision issues? (asked by Gert-Jan Akerboom) A: Use setKinematicTarget inside fixedUpdate ticks with the rigidbody in world space for smooth movement (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Will you be adding bone masks with animation blending? (asked by TheMattEmpire) A: Yes, but you can already do that by keying only the bones you want and excluding the rest (answered by Ashxn)
Q: How do I get screen width/height in hyp app for screen space UI? (asked by shmoji) A: This feature is planned to be added via something like word.viewportWidth, but you shouldn't need it - using pivot, offset and position should handle most UI needs (answered by Ashxn)

## 3. Help Interactions

# Discord Chat Analysis for ğŸ§Šâ”‚3d-design Channel

## 1. Summary
The chat segment contains a brief discussion about 3D design challenges in Hyperfy. Fibelius mentions struggling with a v1 world containing Kitbash 3D buildings and inquires about v2 compatibility and whether purchasing the Kitbash Neo Tokyo kit would be worthwhile for a non-professional designer. HiroP provides technical advice about Kitbash's recent "game ready" kits, noting they're optimized for Unreal Engine with fewer draw calls and better meshes/textures, but still have high poly counts focused on Nanite technology. HiroP warns that Kitbash models would require significant optimization work for Hyperfy and suggests alternatives: looking for low-poly models on platforms like Fab or Artstation, or creating low-poly versions of Kitbash models and projecting textures onto them. Fibelius clarifies their interest in architectural models rather than dystopian cities, mentioning previous work with Alvar Aalto's Villa Mairea. HiroP recommends checking futuristic sculptural buildings from Kitbash and suggests looking at Untitled's MOCA builds which are CC0-licensed.
